newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Former coup leader bids for Venezuelan presidency.
newsitem.headline: Former coup leader bids for Venezuelan presidency.

text.p: The leader of a bloody army coup attempt that shook Venezuela's democracy five years ago announced on Monday he would run for the presidency next year.
Retired Lt. Col. Hugo Chavez, head of the small, left-leaning Boliviariano Revolutionary Movement (MBR-200), said he had "the firm intention of emerging a winner" of the December 1998 election.

"When a soldier goes to battle he wants to win not to lose, and I intend to be Venezuela's Commander in Chief," he told a news conference. He said an opinion poll his movement conducted in 15 cities showed 50 percent of the people were ready to vote for him.
Chavez led a failed rebellon on Feb. 4, 1992, and was jailed for two years until President Rafael Caldera pardoned the rebellious officers shortly after assuming power.
Chavez became the first political leader to proclaim his presidential candidacy officially. Former beauty queen Irene Saez, Venezuela's most popular politician, has hinted she will also run.
Political analysts say MBR-200 is no serious political threat but his populist message laced with leftist rhetoric is effective among the poor.
